questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below: ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Fornix

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers that acts as a major output tract from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies and then onto the thalamus. In the midsagittal section, the fornix is seen as an arching structure that lies inferior to the corpus callosum, the massive fiber tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres. The body of the fornix travels anteriorly and inferiorly, eventually dividing into left and right columns which curve downward in front of the thalamus.
  • ➤ Fornix

questions.text: A patient presented with strong upper limb pulses and weak lower limb pulses with chest x-ray showing rib notching. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coarctation of Aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coarctation of the aorta is identified by the presence of strong upper limb pulses, weak lower limb pulses, and rib notching on a chest x-ray, which is caused by collateral circulation developing around the narrowed section of the aorta.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma in PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Carboprost

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carboprost (PGF2 alpha) is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: Where chemical waste can be disposed? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Yellow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the hospital by her mother. She complaints of pain in the abdomen. On examination her UPT is positive. What will be first step done by you as a medical officer :
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Inform police

questions.text: Criteria for FRU include all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 24-hour MTP facility

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The criteria for a functional First Referral Unit (FRU) include:
  • • criteria for a functional First Referral Unit (FRU)
  • • 24-hour delivery services Emergency obstetric care, including surgical intervention (implying surgical intervention is a criterion) Blood storage facility RTI/STI management Newborn care Care of sick children Full range of family planning services, including safe abortion services (but not explicitly 24-hour MTP facility) Essential laboratory services Transport facility
  • • 24-hour delivery services
  • • Emergency obstetric care, including surgical intervention (implying surgical intervention is a criterion)
  • • Blood storage facility
  • • RTI/STI management
  • • Newborn care
  • • Care of sick children
  • • Full range of family planning services, including safe abortion services (but not explicitly 24-hour MTP facility)
  • • Essential laboratory services
  • • Transport facility
  • • The criteria "not included" for an FRU is the availability of a 24-hour MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) facility. It states that while 24-hour delivery services are available, a 24-hour MTP facility is not explicitly listed as a criterion for an FRU.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a functional First Referral Unit (FRU), the criteria include 24-hour delivery services, emergency obstetric care (including surgical intervention), blood storage facility, RTI/STI management, newborn care, care of sick children, family planning services, essential laboratory services, and transport facility. However, the availability of a 24-hour MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) facility is not explicitly a criterion for an FRU.

questions.text: What is the most common chemistry of gallstones among the following options? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gallstones are crystalline formations that occur in the gallbladder due to the precipitation of substances found in bile. The most common type of gallstones are cholesterol stones, which account for about 80% of all gallstone cases. These stones primarily consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.
  • • Types of Gallstones :
  • • Types of Gallstones
  • • Cholesterol Stones : These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones. Pigment Stones : Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders. Mixed Stones : These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.
  • • Cholesterol Stones : These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones.
  • • Cholesterol Stones
  • • Pigment Stones : Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders.
  • • Pigment Stones
  • • Mixed Stones : These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.
  • • Mixed Stones
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: This is not a common form of gallstones. Cholesterol stones typically form in the monohydrate crystalline structure rather than dihydrate.
  • • Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate:
  • • Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Gallstones are rarely composed of amorphous cholesterol, and the dihydrate form is not typical. The monohydrate crystalline form is the most common.
  • • Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate:
  • • Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Gallstones are generally crystalline in nature rather than amorphous. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate is the most common form found in gallstones.
  • • Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common chemistry of gallstones is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate, which constitutes about 80% of all gallstone cases.

questions.text: Which will you not see in twin pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible configuration in twin pregnancies. The formation of the amnion and chorion follows a specific sequence that does not allow for this combination. Understanding the timing and resulting structures of zygote division is crucial in determining the type of twin pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Barium meal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image is a barium meal. This study is used to examine the stomach and proximal duodenum.
  • • Visual Cues: The image shows the distribution of barium within the stomach, outlining its contours and revealing its internal structure, which is typical in a barium meal examination.
  • • Visual Cues:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Barium Swallow: This study primarily evaluates the esophagus and does not extend into the stomach. The radiograph showing the stomach filled with barium indicates that the procedure goes beyond just a barium swallow.
  • • Option A. Barium Swallow:
  • • Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through: This investigation involves not only the stomach but also a sequential imaging of the small intestine as the barium passes through. The specific image provided does not show barium beyond the proximal duodenum, which is typical in a simple barium meal.
  • • Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through:
  • • Option D. Barium Enema: This procedure is used to visualize the large intestine (colon) and rectum using barium introduced via the rectum. The provided image showing the stomach filled with barium clearly indicates that it's not a barium enema.
  • • Option D. Barium Enema:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.
  • ➤ Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)

questions.text: Identify the correct order of layers incised while performing a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome? ( NEET PG 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia

options.label: D
options.text: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia, Deep fascia and a few muscular fibers

questions.correct_answer: C. Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome, the incision must pass through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia to adequately decompress the affected muscle compartments.

questions.text: A 57-year-old person completed his treatment of leprosy. Two years later, he presents with a punched-out painless ulcer on his sole. What is the next best step in the management? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

questions.correct_answer: A. Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of chronic trophic ulcers in leprosy, reducing pressure on the ulcerated area through weight redistribution, such as with a plaster cast, is essential to promote healing and prevent further complication

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with Luminal A type of breast carcinoma. Which of the following best describes the marker profile in her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.correct_answer: B. ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67
questions.explanation: Ans. B) ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to: (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Variation in cell size and shape

options.label: C
options.text: Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lack of differentiation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anaplasia indicates a high grade of malignancy due to the significant loss of differentiation and structural and functional changes in the neoplastic cells.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a smoker patient who presented as shown in the given image and the next investigation required in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Erythroplakia and Biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythroplakia presents as a red, velvety patch in the oral mucosa and has a high risk of malignant transformation. The appropriate next step in management is to perform a biopsy to determine the presence of dysplasia or carcinoma.

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracking of blood pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracking of blood pressure describes the observation that individuals maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values from childhood to adulthood. This means that blood pressure levels tend to remain consistent relative to peers over time.
  • ➤ Tracking of blood pressure

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.
  • • Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy:
  • • Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.
  • • Option C. Wait and watch:
  • • Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.
  • • Option D. CT scan:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. 2

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the telomerase theory of aging? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Telomere stability is associated with aging

options.label: B
options.text: Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with aging

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased telomere length is associated with aging

options.label: D
options.text: Increased telomere length is associated with aging

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreased telomere length is associated with aging
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decreased telomere length is associated with aging.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decreased telomere length is associated with aging. Telomeres shorten with each cell division, leading to cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis when they become critically short, contributing to the aging process. Telomerase helps prevent this shortening but is typically inactive in most somatic cells, leading to aging and limited cell division capability.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 5-year-old child is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Langerhans cell histiocytosis is the most probable diagnosis given the age of the child, the radiographic appearance of the skull lesion, and the absence of systemic symptoms or biochemical abnormalities typically associated with the other conditions listed.

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dilated cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with alcohol abuse reflects the cumulative detrimental effects of alcohol on heart structure and function, compounded by nutritional deficiencies and genetic factors, making it a critical concern in chronic alcohol consumers.

questions.text: A young male weighing 46 kg was treated with a drug. It has a Vd of 6 L/kg and clearance of 4.6 L/hour. What is the approximate half-life of this drug? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 hours

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The half-life can be calculated using the formula:
  • • t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance
  • • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours
  • • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L
  • • Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula for calculating half-life (t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance) and remember to account for total Vd when given in L/kg by multiplying with body weight.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.correct_answer: D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The fundus and body of the gallbladder are not typically considered anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The gallbladder is situated more to the right and superior to the duodenum, so it is not directly in front of it.
  • • Note - The junction of the first and second parts of the duodenum lies posterior to the neck of the gallbladder. The anterior relations of the third segment of the duodenum comprise the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum
  • • Note -
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Superior mesenteric vessels : The superior mesenteric vessels, which include the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV), are anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The SMA runs just posterior to the third part of the duodenum, and the SMV is typically located to the right of the SMA and also in front of the duodenum.
  • • Option A)
  • • Superior mesenteric vessels
  • • Option B) Loops of jejunum: Loops of the jejunum, which are part of the small intestine, can lie anterior to the third part of the duodenum. The small intestine, including the jejunum, is positioned in the abdominal cavity, and its loops can be found in close proximity to the duodenum.
  • • Option B)
  • • Loops of jejunum:
  • • Option C) Root of mesentery: The root of the mesentery is an extension of the peritoneum that connects the small intestine (including the jejunum and ileum) to the posterior abdominal wall. It passes in front of the third part of the duodenum as it continues to the jejunum and ileum. Therefore, it is an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum.
  • • Option C)
  • • Root of mesentery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: All are the members of the medical board in MTP > 24 weeks, except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Legal advisor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In MTP cases beyond 24 weeks, the medical board consists of medical professionals such as radiologists, gynecologists, and pediatricians, but not legal advisors.

questions.text: Match the following:( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct matching of the procedures with their respective characteristics is as follows:
  • • Amniocentesis (A-4) : This procedure involves the assessment of amniotic fluid, often for detecting alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and other genetic conditions. It is generally performed between 15-18 weeks but may be done later as well. Chorionic Villous Sampling (B-1) : CVS is performed earlier in pregnancy, typically between 10-13 weeks. It involves sampling of placental tissue to test for chromosomal abnormalities and genetic conditions. Fetal Blood Sampling (C-2) : Also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), this procedure is done around 19-20 weeks to obtain fetal blood, often for testing fetal anemia, infections, or genetic conditions. Fetoscopy (D-3) : This procedure involves visualizing the fetus directly in utero and is used in specific circumstances to assess fetal anatomy and perform interventions.
  • • Amniocentesis (A-4) : This procedure involves the assessment of amniotic fluid, often for detecting alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and other genetic conditions. It is generally performed between 15-18 weeks but may be done later as well.
  • • Amniocentesis (A-4)
  • • Chorionic Villous Sampling (B-1) : CVS is performed earlier in pregnancy, typically between 10-13 weeks. It involves sampling of placental tissue to test for chromosomal abnormalities and genetic conditions.
  • • Chorionic Villous Sampling (B-1)
  • • Fetal Blood Sampling (C-2) : Also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), this procedure is done around 19-20 weeks to obtain fetal blood, often for testing fetal anemia, infections, or genetic conditions.
  • • Fetal Blood Sampling (C-2)
  • • Fetoscopy (D-3) : This procedure involves visualizing the fetus directly in utero and is used in specific circumstances to assess fetal anatomy and perform interventions.
  • • Fetoscopy (D-3)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1 : Incorrect because Chorionic Villous Sampling (CVS) is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetoscopy does not typically involve amniotic fluid assessment.
  • • Option A. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1
  • • Option B. A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4 : Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetal blood sampling is not done at 8-12 weeks.
  • • Option B. A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4
  • • Option D. A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1 : Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not used to visualize fetal organs, and Chorionic Villous Sampling is not done at 19-20 weeks.
  • • Option D. A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the appropriate timing and purpose of various prenatal diagnostic procedures such as Amniocentesis, Chorionic Villous Sampling, Fetal Blood Sampling, and Fetoscopy.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 882, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 741
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 882, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 741

questions.text: All of the following structure pass through the aortic opening of diaphragm except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxygen saturation

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulse oximetry measures the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of hemoglobin in the blood using the principles of Beer Lambert’s law and plethysmography.

questions.text: What concentration of fluoride is typically associated with causing crippling fluorosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ‘Fluorine is a double edged sword’: Inadequate intake is associated with ‘dental caries’ whereas excess intake with ‘dental and skeletal fluorosis’
  • ➤ Crippling fluorosis occurs when fluoride levels in drinking water exceed 10 mg/L, leading to severe and disabling conditions.

questions.text: A patient suffered burns following which the surgical procedure was done as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the likely procedure done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A meshed appearance on a graft used for burn treatment indicates a Thiersch skin graft (split-thickness skin graft), which is designed to cover a larger area and facilitate exudate drainage.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Humerus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.
  • ➤ The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute onset of double vision, difficulty walking, and confusion. Given a history of alcohol abuse, what is the most appropriate initial treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intravenous thiamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion, should be treated immediately with intravenous thiamine to prevent serious neurological damage.

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment

options.label: B
options.text: Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

options.label: C
options.text: In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG

options.label: D
options.text: Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.correct_answer: B. Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg127
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg127

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of cervical erosion and spotting since 2 months. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  LBC + HPV + cervical biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with cervical erosion and spotting, the best approach is to screen for cervical cancer with LBC, HPV testing, and a cervical biopsy if indicated.

questions.text: Outlet forceps is applied at what station? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Head on perineum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Outlet forceps are applied when the fetal head is visible at the perineum, indicating it is at the outlet of the birth canal.

questions.text: Reason of Hepatomegaly in Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Accumulation of glycogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.

questions.text: A patient experiences chest pain radiating to the arm. Which nerve can be responsible for the radiating pain? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intercostobrachial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intercostobrachial nerve, originating from T2, is responsible for the sensation in the upper medial arm and can be involved in referred pain from the chest, such as during a myocardial infarction. This nerve is key in understanding the dermatome distribution related to cardiac pain.

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male, employed as a welder, presents with the following eye symptoms: pain, redness, and excessive tearing. What would be the appropriate next step in managing this condition?( FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Remove with 26G needle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate management of a corneal foreign body, especially in an occupational setting like welding, involves careful removal using a sterile hypodermic needle, followed by the application of antibiotic ointment to prevent infection.

questions.text: A 74-year-old male presents to the hospital with urinary hesitancy and retention of urine. An ultrasound reveals an enlarged prostate and a residual urine volume of 130 ml. Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of this patient? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5 alpha-reductase inhibitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are used to treat urinary symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by reducing the size of the prostate and relieving urinary hesitancy and retention.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. The patient is dehydrated and the blood pressure of the patient is 90/60 mm Hg. Laboratory investigations revealed the serum potassium level of 6.0 mEq/L, sodium level of 129 mEq/L, and blood glucose level of 40 mg/dL. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) for which he was prescribed medication by a local physician; however, the patient abruptly discontinued the medication a few weeks ago. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following drugs should be administered as a life-saving measure to treat this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hydrocortisone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrocortisone is the drug of choice for treating adrenal insufficiency or Addisonian crisis, which can present with hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, dehydration, and hypoglycemia, especially in patients with a history of corticosteroid use who abruptly discontinue their medication.
